ASP.NET Core: Map vs. UseWhen 🤔🟢 What’s the Difference? 🟢 When to Use Which? If you’ve ever worked with middleware in ASP.NET Core, you’ve probably come across Map and UseWhen. At first glance, they seem similar—but they serve different purposes! Let’s break it down in a way that actually makes sense.🎯 Think of Map like a fork in the road.When a request matches a specific path, it permanently takes a separate route (middleware branch).Example: If the request starts with /admin, handle it differently from /user.·Once a request enters a Map branch, it does not return to the main pipeline.🎯 Now, UseWhen is like a side road that merges back.It conditionally applies middleware based on any condition (query params, headers, request type, etc.).But unlike Map, the request returns to the main pipeline afterward.🚀 Example: Imagine a Coffee Shop ☕️Think of an ASP.NET Core middleware pipeline like a coffee shop where customers (requests) come in, get their orders processed, and leave with a response.📌 Map → Separate Lanes for VIPs and Regular Customers In our coffee shop, we have two separate counters:One exclusively for VIP customers.Another for regular customers. If a customer goes to the VIP counter, they never interact with the regular counter.💡 How This Works:If a customer (request) enters /vip, they are directed only to the VIP Rest.If they go anywhere else (/, /home, etc.), they never see the VIP Lounge—they get the regular coffee experience.📌 UseWhen → Special Offers for Customers Wearing Glasses 🤓 Now, let's say the coffee shop offers a discount for customers wearing glasses, but they still follow the same ordering process as everyone else.If someone is wearing glasses, they get extra middleware (discount applied) but still follow the regular checkout.If they aren't wearing glasses, they simply proceed without the discount.💡 How This Works:If the request contains ?glasses=true, it applies the discount (executes the UseWhen middleware).But after the discount is applied, the request continues in the regular pipeline (everyone still gets coffee).If ?glasses=true is not present, the customer still gets coffee but without the discount.🎯 Use Map when requests should take completely separate paths (VIP vs. Regular customers).🎯 Use UseWhen when requests need temporary processing but should still follow the main flow (Glasses discount).

【2024年度QBICプログラム「キャリアと実践Ⅰ 」に学生メンターとして参加】2025年2月8日、QBICプログラムが提供する「キャリアと実践Ⅰ」の最終発表会が行われました。QBICプログラム(Question-Based Innovation and Career education program for societal transition)は、転換期の社会に求められる力を培うための産学速型教育プログラムです。「キャリアと実践Ⅰ」は、本プログラムの科目の一つであり、大阪公立大学の学生が、異なる分野や学年で構成されるグループを作り、「都市大阪の20年後（2045年）の未来社会を創造し，「今」自分たちが取りくむべき課題を設定する」というテーマに取り組みます。グループには、受講生の他に、以前本プログラムを受講していた学生が学生メンターとして、さらに、パナソニックや清水建設、日立製作所、リンクアンドモチベーションなどといった、日本を代表する企業の人事の方が社会人メンターとして加わります。今回も受講生らは、自分とは異なる立場の人達と、20年後の都市大阪の未来を共創する取り組みの中で、「問いを立てる力」と、「学び続ける力」を身につけ、大きく成長させることができました。今回私は、学生メンターとして本プログラムに参加しました。受講生の先輩としてミーティング中にアドバイスしたり、社会人メンターとやりとりしたりし、非常に貴重な経験をさせていただきました。受講生の頃からこれでもかというくらい多くの知識やスキルを与えてくださった市田先生には感謝しかないです。また、本プログラムを主催している先生方や企業の方たちはお金のためにやっているのではなく、日本をよくしていこうという熱いマインドを持たれていて、非常に尊敬しました。本プログラムのさらなる拡大をお祈りしております。この春からいよいよ社会人ですが、熱い心と謙虚な姿勢で社会に価値を与えられる存在になりたいと思います！https://lnkd.in/dbk5rFhZhashtag#大阪公立大学 hashtag#QBIC hashtag#共創

It’s time companies started seeing autistic people as assets, not obstacles!This is the first time I’m openly admitting that I’m autistic (Asperger) beyond my close family and friends. It’s something I’ve kept to myself for a long time because, frankly, it’s not easy. Every word you say can make you feel like an outsider, as if people see you as “weird.” So, the instinct is to hide it, to avoid declaring it, and to struggle against the pressure to conform.But my brother—who works in education and supports people with autism, dyslexia, and other neurodivergences—recently said something that really stuck with me: Autism isn’t a hindrance; it’s a superpower! I was genuinely touched because, honestly, I often worry that he doesn’t see me that way.For example, when I approach a problem, I see the big picture, while many “neurotypical” people focus only on what’s right in front of them. This ability is especially valuable in programming, where structure, logic, and attention to detail are essential. Autistic people often excel in programming and technical fields because of their ability to spot patterns, think systematically, and work with incredible focus.But what’s frustrating is when others can’t see the big picture and block progress because they’re stuck on minor details or rigid ways of thinking. It’s exhausting to have a clear vision of how things should work, only to be told, “That’s not how we do it,” by people who refuse to see beyond their own limited perspective. This is one of the biggest challenges autistic people face in the workplace—not our abilities, but the barriers put in our way by those who don’t understand them.Some companies fail to see the value in this. But the best ones do, and they recognise the incredible strengths that autistic minds bring.This conversation has really lifted my spirits. I love seeing more people acknowledge that autistic individuals have so much to offer when given the right environment to thrive—especially in fields like programming, where our strengths shine!Well done Murphy for setting a new standard!

ASP.NET Core: Map vs. UseWhen 🤔🟢 What’s the Difference? 🟢 When to Use Which? If you’ve ever worked with middleware in ASP.NET Core, you’ve probably come across Map and UseWhen. At first glance, they seem similar—but they serve different purposes! Let’s break it down in a way that actually makes sense.🎯 Think of Map like a fork in the road.When a request matches a specific path, it permanently takes a separate route (middleware branch).Example: If the request starts with /admin, handle it differently from /user.·Once a request enters a Map branch, it does not return to the main pipeline.🎯 Now, UseWhen is like a side road that merges back.It conditionally applies middleware based on any condition (query params, headers, request type, etc.).But unlike Map, the request returns to the main pipeline afterward.🚀 Example: Imagine a Coffee Shop ☕️Think of an ASP.NET Core middleware pipeline like a coffee shop where customers (requests) come in, get their orders processed, and leave with a response.📌 Map → Separate Lanes for VIPs and Regular Customers In our coffee shop, we have two separate counters:One exclusively for VIP customers.Another for regular customers. If a customer goes to the VIP counter, they never interact with the regular counter.💡 How This Works:If a customer (request) enters /vip, they are directed only to the VIP Rest.If they go anywhere else (/, /home, etc.), they never see the VIP Lounge—they get the regular coffee experience.📌 UseWhen → Special Offers for Customers Wearing Glasses 🤓 Now, let's say the coffee shop offers a discount for customers wearing glasses, but they still follow the same ordering process as everyone else.If someone is wearing glasses, they get extra middleware (discount applied) but still follow the regular checkout.If they aren't wearing glasses, they simply proceed without the discount.💡 How This Works:If the request contains ?glasses=true, it applies the discount (executes the UseWhen middleware).But after the discount is applied, the request continues in the regular pipeline (everyone still gets coffee).If ?glasses=true is not present, the customer still gets coffee but without the discount.🎯 Use Map when requests should take completely separate paths (VIP vs. Regular customers).🎯 Use UseWhen when requests need temporary processing but should still follow the main flow (Glasses discount).

【2024年度QBICプログラム「キャリアと実践Ⅰ 」に学生メンターとして参加】2025年2月8日、QBICプログラムが提供する「キャリアと実践Ⅰ」の最終発表会が行われました。QBICプログラム(Question-Based Innovation and Career education program for societal transition)は、転換期の社会に求められる力を培うための産学速型教育プログラムです。「キャリアと実践Ⅰ」は、本プログラムの科目の一つであり、大阪公立大学の学生が、異なる分野や学年で構成されるグループを作り、「都市大阪の20年後（2045年）の未来社会を創造し，「今」自分たちが取りくむべき課題を設定する」というテーマに取り組みます。グループには、受講生の他に、以前本プログラムを受講していた学生が学生メンターとして、さらに、パナソニックや清水建設、日立製作所、リンクアンドモチベーションなどといった、日本を代表する企業の人事の方が社会人メンターとして加わります。今回も受講生らは、自分とは異なる立場の人達と、20年後の都市大阪の未来を共創する取り組みの中で、「問いを立てる力」と、「学び続ける力」を身につけ、大きく成長させることができました。今回私は、学生メンターとして本プログラムに参加しました。受講生の先輩としてミーティング中にアドバイスしたり、社会人メンターとやりとりしたりし、非常に貴重な経験をさせていただきました。受講生の頃からこれでもかというくらい多くの知識やスキルを与えてくださった市田先生には感謝しかないです。また、本プログラムを主催している先生方や企業の方たちはお金のためにやっているのではなく、日本をよくしていこうという熱いマインドを持たれていて、非常に尊敬しました。本プログラムのさらなる拡大をお祈りしております。この春からいよいよ社会人ですが、熱い心と謙虚な姿勢で社会に価値を与えられる存在になりたいと思います！https://lnkd.in/dbk5rFhZhashtag#大阪公立大学 hashtag#QBIC hashtag#共創

🚨 Dear Fake Recruiters, We See You! 🚨Hey there, legendary "recruiters" of LinkedIn! You know who you are – the ones offering dream jobs with “amazing opportunities” but somehow… things never quite add up. Let’s break down your hiring process, shall we? 😂📢 Step 1: The Perfect Job Post“We’re looking for a highly motivated, dynamic, results-driven individual who can work under pressure, multitask, lead a team, work independently, and also be a team player. Oh, and fresh graduates welcome!”Translation: We have no idea what we want, but we’ll still act like we do.📢 Step 2: The Too-Good-To-Be-True Salary"Salary: Competitive."Translation: You’ll find out at the last stage… or never.📢 Step 3: The Interview ProcessRound 1: A quick call filled with enthusiasm. "You’re the PERFECT fit for this role!"Round 2: A panel interview where no one from the company seems to know who you are.Round 3: A surprise "assignment" requiring 20 hours of unpaid labor.Final Round: Complete silence. Poof! You’ve been ghosted. 👻📢 Step 4: The Random DM Recruiter"Hello dear, I saw your profile and I have a great opportunity for you. Kindly share your CV and WhatsApp number."Bonus Points: If the company name doesn’t exist on Google. 😆To all the real recruiters out there doing an honest job, we salute you! 🫡 But to the fake ones – we see you, and we’re taking screenshots. 😏Tag a friend who's been ghosted or scammed by a fake recruiter! 😂👇hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#Recruitment hashtag#Hiring hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#InterviewTips hashtag#JobHunt hashtag#ResumeTips hashtag#CareerAdvice hashtag#JobSeeker hashtag#WorkLife hashtag#LinkedInHumor hashtag#HiringNow hashtag#JobOpening hashtag#WorkFromHome hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#HRLife hashtag#HumanResources hashtag#Recruiting hashtag#RecruiterLife hashtag#LinkedInNetworking hashtag#FakeJobs hashtag#CareerTips hashtag#InterviewFail hashtag#JobHuntingStruggles hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#ProfessionalGrowth hashtag#LinkedInCommunity hashtag#HiringAlert hashtag#JobInterview hashtag#GhostedByRecruiters hashtag#JobMarket hashtag#ResumeHelp hashtag#CareerMotivation hashtag#WorkplaceHumor hashtag#JobSearchStruggles hashtag#RecruiterFails hashtag#JobScams hashtag#ScamAlert hashtag#JobSeekerJourney hashtag#WorkHardPlayHard hashtag#OfficeHumor hashtag#LinkedInMarketing hashtag#JobOffers hashtag#CorporateHumor hashtag#CareerOppo hashtag#letsconnect

It’s time companies started seeing autistic people as assets, not obstacles!This is the first time I’m openly admitting that I’m autistic (Asperger) beyond my close family and friends. It’s something I’ve kept to myself for a long time because, frankly, it’s not easy. Every word you say can make you feel like an outsider, as if people see you as “weird.” So, the instinct is to hide it, to avoid declaring it, and to struggle against the pressure to conform.But my brother—who works in education and supports people with autism, dyslexia, and other neurodivergences—recently said something that really stuck with me: Autism isn’t a hindrance; it’s a superpower! I was genuinely touched because, honestly, I often worry that he doesn’t see me that way.For example, when I approach a problem, I see the big picture, while many “neurotypical” people focus only on what’s right in front of them. This ability is especially valuable in programming, where structure, logic, and attention to detail are essential. Autistic people often excel in programming and technical fields because of their ability to spot patterns, think systematically, and work with incredible focus.But what’s frustrating is when others can’t see the big picture and block progress because they’re stuck on minor details or rigid ways of thinking. It’s exhausting to have a clear vision of how things should work, only to be told, “That’s not how we do it,” by people who refuse to see beyond their own limited perspective. This is one of the biggest challenges autistic people face in the workplace—not our abilities, but the barriers put in our way by those who don’t understand them.Some companies fail to see the value in this. But the best ones do, and they recognise the incredible strengths that autistic minds bring.This conversation has really lifted my spirits. I love seeing more people acknowledge that autistic individuals have so much to offer when given the right environment to thrive—especially in fields like programming, where our strengths shine!Well done Murphy for setting a new standard!

ASP.NET Core: Map vs. UseWhen 🤔🟢 What’s the Difference? 🟢 When to Use Which? If you’ve ever worked with middleware in ASP.NET Core, you’ve probably come across Map and UseWhen. At first glance, they seem similar—but they serve different purposes! Let’s break it down in a way that actually makes sense.🎯 Think of Map like a fork in the road.When a request matches a specific path, it permanently takes a separate route (middleware branch).Example: If the request starts with /admin, handle it differently from /user.·Once a request enters a Map branch, it does not return to the main pipeline.🎯 Now, UseWhen is like a side road that merges back.It conditionally applies middleware based on any condition (query params, headers, request type, etc.).But unlike Map, the request returns to the main pipeline afterward.🚀 Example: Imagine a Coffee Shop ☕️Think of an ASP.NET Core middleware pipeline like a coffee shop where customers (requests) come in, get their orders processed, and leave with a response.📌 Map → Separate Lanes for VIPs and Regular Customers In our coffee shop, we have two separate counters:One exclusively for VIP customers.Another for regular customers. If a customer goes to the VIP counter, they never interact with the regular counter.💡 How This Works:If a customer (request) enters /vip, they are directed only to the VIP Rest.If they go anywhere else (/, /home, etc.), they never see the VIP Lounge—they get the regular coffee experience.📌 UseWhen → Special Offers for Customers Wearing Glasses 🤓 Now, let's say the coffee shop offers a discount for customers wearing glasses, but they still follow the same ordering process as everyone else.If someone is wearing glasses, they get extra middleware (discount applied) but still follow the regular checkout.If they aren't wearing glasses, they simply proceed without the discount.💡 How This Works:If the request contains ?glasses=true, it applies the discount (executes the UseWhen middleware).But after the discount is applied, the request continues in the regular pipeline (everyone still gets coffee).If ?glasses=true is not present, the customer still gets coffee but without the discount.🎯 Use Map when requests should take completely separate paths (VIP vs. Regular customers).🎯 Use UseWhen when requests need temporary processing but should still follow the main flow (Glasses discount).

【2024年度QBICプログラム「キャリアと実践Ⅰ 」に学生メンターとして参加】2025年2月8日、QBICプログラムが提供する「キャリアと実践Ⅰ」の最終発表会が行われました。QBICプログラム(Question-Based Innovation and Career education program for societal transition)は、転換期の社会に求められる力を培うための産学速型教育プログラムです。「キャリアと実践Ⅰ」は、本プログラムの科目の一つであり、大阪公立大学の学生が、異なる分野や学年で構成されるグループを作り、「都市大阪の20年後（2045年）の未来社会を創造し，「今」自分たちが取りくむべき課題を設定する」というテーマに取り組みます。グループには、受講生の他に、以前本プログラムを受講していた学生が学生メンターとして、さらに、パナソニックや清水建設、日立製作所、リンクアンドモチベーションなどといった、日本を代表する企業の人事の方が社会人メンターとして加わります。今回も受講生らは、自分とは異なる立場の人達と、20年後の都市大阪の未来を共創する取り組みの中で、「問いを立てる力」と、「学び続ける力」を身につけ、大きく成長させることができました。今回私は、学生メンターとして本プログラムに参加しました。受講生の先輩としてミーティング中にアドバイスしたり、社会人メンターとやりとりしたりし、非常に貴重な経験をさせていただきました。受講生の頃からこれでもかというくらい多くの知識やスキルを与えてくださった市田先生には感謝しかないです。また、本プログラムを主催している先生方や企業の方たちはお金のためにやっているのではなく、日本をよくしていこうという熱いマインドを持たれていて、非常に尊敬しました。本プログラムのさらなる拡大をお祈りしております。この春からいよいよ社会人ですが、熱い心と謙虚な姿勢で社会に価値を与えられる存在になりたいと思います！https://lnkd.in/dbk5rFhZhashtag#大阪公立大学 hashtag#QBIC hashtag#共創

You know who you are – the ones offering dream jobs with “amazing opportunities” but somehow… things never quite add up. Let’s break down your hiring process, shall we? 😂📢 Step 1: The Perfect Job Post“We’re looking for a highly motivated, dynamic, results-driven individual who can work under pressure, multitask, lead a team, work independently, and also be a team player. Poof! You’ve been ghosted. 👻📢 Step 4: The Random DM Recruiter"Hello dear, I saw your profile and I have a great opportunity for you. It’s time companies started seeing autistic people as assets, not obstacles!This is the first time I’m openly admitting that I’m autistic (Asperger) beyond my close family and friends. It’s something I’ve kept to myself for a long time because, frankly, it’s not easy. Every word you say can make you feel like an outsider, as if people see you as “weird.” So, the instinct is to hide it, to avoid declaring it, and to struggle against the pressure to conform.But my brother—who works in education and supports people with autism, dyslexia, and other neurodivergences—recently said something that really stuck with me: Autism isn’t a hindrance; it’s a superpower! I was genuinely touched because, honestly, I often worry that he doesn’t see me that way.For example, when I approach a problem, I see the big picture, while many “neurotypical” people focus only on what’s right in front of them. This ability is especially valuable in programming, where structure, logic, and attention to detail are essential. Autistic people often excel in programming and technical fields because of their ability to spot patterns, think systematically, and work with incredible focus.But what’s frustrating is when others can’t see the big picture and block progress because they’re stuck on minor details or rigid ways of thinking. It’s exhausting to have a clear vision of how things should work, only to be told, “That’s not how we do it,” by people who refuse to see beyond their own limited perspective. This is one of the biggest challenges autistic people face in the workplace—not our abilities, but the barriers put in our way by those who don’t understand them.Some companies fail to see the value in this. But the best ones do, and they recognise the incredible strengths that autistic minds bring.This conversation has really lifted my spirits. I love seeing more people acknowledge that autistic individuals have so much to offer when given the right environment to thrive—especially in fields like programming, where our strengths shine!Well done Murphy for setting a new standard!

ASP.NET Core: Map vs. UseWhen 🤔🟢 What’s the Difference? 🟢 When to Use Which? If you’ve ever worked with middleware in ASP.NET Core, you’ve probably come across Map and UseWhen. At first glance, they seem similar—but they serve different purposes! Let’s break it down in a way that actually makes sense.🎯 Think of Map like a fork in the road.When a request matches a specific path, it permanently takes a separate route (middleware branch).Example: If the request starts with /admin, handle it differently from /user.·Once a request enters a Map branch, it does not return to the main pipeline.🎯 Now, UseWhen is like a side road that merges back.It conditionally applies middleware based on any condition (query params, headers, request type, etc.).But unlike Map, the request returns to the main pipeline afterward.🚀 Example: Imagine a Coffee Shop ☕️Think of an ASP.NET Core middleware pipeline like a coffee shop where customers (requests) come in, get their orders processed, and leave with a response.📌 Map → Separate Lanes for VIPs and Regular Customers In our coffee shop, we have two separate counters:One exclusively for VIP customers.Another for regular customers. If a customer goes to the VIP counter, they never interact with the regular counter.💡 How This Works:If a customer (request) enters /vip, they are directed only to the VIP Rest.If they go anywhere else (/, /home, etc.), they never see the VIP Lounge—they get the regular coffee experience.📌 UseWhen → Special Offers for Customers Wearing Glasses 🤓 Now, let's say the coffee shop offers a discount for customers wearing glasses, but they still follow the same ordering process as everyone else.If someone is wearing glasses, they get extra middleware (discount applied) but still follow the regular checkout.If they aren't wearing glasses, they simply proceed without the discount.💡 How This Works:If the request contains ?glasses=true, it applies the discount (executes the UseWhen middleware).But after the discount is applied, the request continues in the regular pipeline (everyone still gets coffee).If ?glasses=true is not present, the customer still gets coffee but without the discount.🎯 Use Map when requests should take completely separate paths (VIP vs. Regular customers).🎯 Use UseWhen when requests need temporary processing but should still follow the main flow (Glasses discount).

【2024年度QBICプログラム「キャリアと実践Ⅰ 」に学生メンターとして参加】2025年2月8日、QBICプログラムが提供する「キャリアと実践Ⅰ」の最終発表会が行われました。QBICプログラム(Question-Based Innovation and Career education program for societal transition)は、転換期の社会に求められる力を培うための産学速型教育プログラムです。「キャリアと実践Ⅰ」は、本プログラムの科目の一つであり、大阪公立大学の学生が、異なる分野や学年で構成されるグループを作り、「都市大阪の20年後（2045年）の未来社会を創造し，「今」自分たちが取りくむべき課題を設定する」というテーマに取り組みます。グループには、受講生の他に、以前本プログラムを受講していた学生が学生メンターとして、さらに、パナソニックや清水建設、日立製作所、リンクアンドモチベーションなどといった、日本を代表する企業の人事の方が社会人メンターとして加わります。今回も受講生らは、自分とは異なる立場の人達と、20年後の都市大阪の未来を共創する取り組みの中で、「問いを立てる力」と、「学び続ける力」を身につけ、大きく成長させることができました。今回私は、学生メンターとして本プログラムに参加しました。受講生の先輩としてミーティング中にアドバイスしたり、社会人メンターとやりとりしたりし、非常に貴重な経験をさせていただきました。受講生の頃からこれでもかというくらい多くの知識やスキルを与えてくださった市田先生には感謝しかないです。また、本プログラムを主催している先生方や企業の方たちはお金のためにやっているのではなく、日本をよくしていこうという熱いマインドを持たれていて、非常に尊敬しました。本プログラムのさらなる拡大をお祈りしております。この春からいよいよ社会人ですが、熱い心と謙虚な姿勢で社会に価値を与えられる存在になりたいと思います！https://lnkd.in/dbk5rFhZhashtag#大阪公立大学 hashtag#QBIC hashtag#共創

You know who you are – the ones offering dream jobs with “amazing opportunities” but somehow… things never quite add up. Let’s break down your hiring process, shall we? 😂📢 Step 1: The Perfect Job Post“We’re looking for a highly motivated, dynamic, results-driven individual who can work under pressure, multitask, lead a team, work independently, and also be a team player. Poof! You’ve been ghosted. 👻📢 Step 4: The Random DM Recruiter"Hello dear, I saw your profile and I have a great opportunity for you. It’s time companies started seeing autistic people as assets, not obstacles!This is the first time I’m openly admitting that I’m autistic (Asperger) beyond my close family and friends. It’s something I’ve kept to myself for a long time because, frankly, it’s not easy. Every word you say can make you feel like an outsider, as if people see you as “weird.” So, the instinct is to hide it, to avoid declaring it, and to struggle against the pressure to conform.But my brother—who works in education and supports people with autism, dyslexia, and other neurodivergences—recently said something that really stuck with me: Autism isn’t a hindrance; it’s a superpower! I was genuinely touched because, honestly, I often worry that he doesn’t see me that way.For example, when I approach a problem, I see the big picture, while many “neurotypical” people focus only on what’s right in front of them. This ability is especially valuable in programming, where structure, logic, and attention to detail are essential. Autistic people often excel in programming and technical fields because of their ability to spot patterns, think systematically, and work with incredible focus.But what’s frustrating is when others can’t see the big picture and block progress because they’re stuck on minor details or rigid ways of thinking. It’s exhausting to have a clear vision of how things should work, only to be told, “That’s not how we do it,” by people who refuse to see beyond their own limited perspective. This is one of the biggest challenges autistic people face in the workplace—not our abilities, but the barriers put in our way by those who don’t understand them.Some companies fail to see the value in this. But the best ones do, and they recognise the incredible strengths that autistic minds bring.This conversation has really lifted my spirits. I love seeing more people acknowledge that autistic individuals have so much to offer when given the right environment to thrive—especially in fields like programming, where our strengths shine!Well done Murphy for setting a new standard!

ASP.NET Core: Map vs. UseWhen 🤔🟢 What’s the Difference? 🟢 When to Use Which? If you’ve ever worked with middleware in ASP.NET Core, you’ve probably come across Map and UseWhen. At first glance, they seem similar—but they serve different purposes! Let’s break it down in a way that actually makes sense.🎯 Think of Map like a fork in the road.When a request matches a specific path, it permanently takes a separate route (middleware branch).Example: If the request starts with /admin, handle it differently from /user.·Once a request enters a Map branch, it does not return to the main pipeline.🎯 Now, UseWhen is like a side road that merges back.It conditionally applies middleware based on any condition (query params, headers, request type, etc.).But unlike Map, the request returns to the main pipeline afterward.🚀 Example: Imagine a Coffee Shop ☕️Think of an ASP.NET Core middleware pipeline like a coffee shop where customers (requests) come in, get their orders processed, and leave with a response.📌 Map → Separate Lanes for VIPs and Regular Customers In our coffee shop, we have two separate counters:One exclusively for VIP customers.Another for regular customers. If a customer goes to the VIP counter, they never interact with the regular counter.💡 How This Works:If a customer (request) enters /vip, they are directed only to the VIP Rest.If they go anywhere else (/, /home, etc.), they never see the VIP Lounge—they get the regular coffee experience.📌 UseWhen → Special Offers for Customers Wearing Glasses 🤓 Now, let's say the coffee shop offers a discount for customers wearing glasses, but they still follow the same ordering process as everyone else.If someone is wearing glasses, they get extra middleware (discount applied) but still follow the regular checkout.If they aren't wearing glasses, they simply proceed without the discount.💡 How This Works:If the request contains ?glasses=true, it applies the discount (executes the UseWhen middleware).But after the discount is applied, the request continues in the regular pipeline (everyone still gets coffee).If ?glasses=true is not present, the customer still gets coffee but without the discount.🎯 Use Map when requests should take completely separate paths (VIP vs. Regular customers).🎯 Use UseWhen when requests need temporary processing but should still follow the main flow (Glasses discount).

【2024年度QBICプログラム「キャリアと実践Ⅰ 」に学生メンターとして参加】2025年2月8日、QBICプログラムが提供する「キャリアと実践Ⅰ」の最終発表会が行われました。QBICプログラム(Question-Based Innovation and Career education program for societal transition)は、転換期の社会に求められる力を培うための産学速型教育プログラムです。「キャリアと実践Ⅰ」は、本プログラムの科目の一つであり、大阪公立大学の学生が、異なる分野や学年で構成されるグループを作り、「都市大阪の20年後（2045年）の未来社会を創造し，「今」自分たちが取りくむべき課題を設定する」というテーマに取り組みます。グループには、受講生の他に、以前本プログラムを受講していた学生が学生メンターとして、さらに、パナソニックや清水建設、日立製作所、リンクアンドモチベーションなどといった、日本を代表する企業の人事の方が社会人メンターとして加わります。今回も受講生らは、自分とは異なる立場の人達と、20年後の都市大阪の未来を共創する取り組みの中で、「問いを立てる力」と、「学び続ける力」を身につけ、大きく成長させることができました。今回私は、学生メンターとして本プログラムに参加しました。受講生の先輩としてミーティング中にアドバイスしたり、社会人メンターとやりとりしたりし、非常に貴重な経験をさせていただきました。受講生の頃からこれでもかというくらい多くの知識やスキルを与えてくださった市田先生には感謝しかないです。また、本プログラムを主催している先生方や企業の方たちはお金のためにやっているのではなく、日本をよくしていこうという熱いマインドを持たれていて、非常に尊敬しました。本プログラムのさらなる拡大をお祈りしております。この春からいよいよ社会人ですが、熱い心と謙虚な姿勢で社会に価値を与えられる存在になりたいと思います！https://lnkd.in/dbk5rFhZhashtag#大阪公立大学 hashtag#QBIC hashtag#共創

🚨 Dear Fake Recruiters, We See You! 🚨Hey there, legendary "recruiters" of LinkedIn! You know who you are – the ones offering dream jobs with “amazing opportunities” but somehow… things never quite add up. Let’s break down your hiring process, shall we? 😂📢 Step 1: The Perfect Job Post“We’re looking for a highly motivated, dynamic, results-driven individual who can work under pressure, multitask, lead a team, work independently, and also be a team player. Oh, and fresh graduates welcome!”Translation: We have no idea what we want, but we’ll still act like we do.📢 Step 2: The Too-Good-To-Be-True Salary"Salary: Competitive."Translation: You’ll find out at the last stage… or never.📢 Step 3: The Interview ProcessRound 1: A quick call filled with enthusiasm. "You’re the PERFECT fit for this role!"Round 2: A panel interview where no one from the company seems to know who you are.Round 3: A surprise "assignment" requiring 20 hours of unpaid labor.Final Round: Complete silence. Poof! You’ve been ghosted. 👻📢 Step 4: The Random DM Recruiter"Hello dear, I saw your profile and I have a great opportunity for you. Kindly share your CV and WhatsApp number."Bonus Points: If the company name doesn’t exist on Google. 😆To all the real recruiters out there doing an honest job, we salute you! 🫡 But to the fake ones – we see you, and we’re taking screenshots. 😏Tag a friend who's been ghosted or scammed by a fake recruiter! 😂👇hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#Recruitment hashtag#Hiring hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#InterviewTips hashtag#JobHunt hashtag#ResumeTips hashtag#CareerAdvice hashtag#JobSeeker hashtag#WorkLife hashtag#LinkedInHumor hashtag#HiringNow hashtag#JobOpening hashtag#WorkFromHome hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#HRLife hashtag#HumanResources hashtag#Recruiting hashtag#RecruiterLife hashtag#LinkedInNetworking hashtag#FakeJobs hashtag#CareerTips hashtag#InterviewFail hashtag#JobHuntingStruggles hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#ProfessionalGrowth hashtag#LinkedInCommunity hashtag#HiringAlert hashtag#JobInterview hashtag#GhostedByRecruiters hashtag#JobMarket hashtag#ResumeHelp hashtag#CareerMotivation hashtag#WorkplaceHumor hashtag#JobSearchStruggles hashtag#RecruiterFails hashtag#JobScams hashtag#ScamAlert hashtag#JobSeekerJourney hashtag#WorkHardPlayHard hashtag#OfficeHumor hashtag#LinkedInMarketing hashtag#JobOffers hashtag#CorporateHumor hashtag#CareerOppo hashtag#letsconnect

It’s time companies started seeing autistic people as assets, not obstacles!This is the first time I’m openly admitting that I’m autistic (Asperger) beyond my close family and friends. It’s something I’ve kept to myself for a long time because, frankly, it’s not easy. Every word you say can make you feel like an outsider, as if people see you as “weird.” So, the instinct is to hide it, to avoid declaring it, and to struggle against the pressure to conform.But my brother—who works in education and supports people with autism, dyslexia, and other neurodivergences—recently said something that really stuck with me: Autism isn’t a hindrance; it’s a superpower! I was genuinely touched because, honestly, I often worry that he doesn’t see me that way.For example, when I approach a problem, I see the big picture, while many “neurotypical” people focus only on what’s right in front of them. This ability is especially valuable in programming, where structure, logic, and attention to detail are essential. Autistic people often excel in programming and technical fields because of their ability to spot patterns, think systematically, and work with incredible focus.But what’s frustrating is when others can’t see the big picture and block progress because they’re stuck on minor details or rigid ways of thinking. It’s exhausting to have a clear vision of how things should work, only to be told, “That’s not how we do it,” by people who refuse to see beyond their own limited perspective. This is one of the biggest challenges autistic people face in the workplace—not our abilities, but the barriers put in our way by those who don’t understand them.Some companies fail to see the value in this. But the best ones do, and they recognise the incredible strengths that autistic minds bring.This conversation has really lifted my spirits. I love seeing more people acknowledge that autistic individuals have so much to offer when given the right environment to thrive—especially in fields like programming, where our strengths shine!Well done Murphy for setting a new standard!

The call to arms!!! hashtag#EngineeringSurveyingEspisode 3 How many hashtag#EngineeringSurveying hashtag#Apprentices are you employing this year and future years to deliver your hashtag#CivilEngineering hashtag#Projects ????The journey continues increasing numbers of hashtag#EngineeringSurveyors in the industry. Today was the L3 and L6 Geospatial Apprenticeship Trailblazer Group Meeting hosted by Lucy Powers BA (Hons), MBA, FInstCES and Alison Watson MBE. I was invited to present what we Balfour Beatty plc are doing to attract future hashtag#Apprentices in to hashtag#BalfourBeatty. The slide which got the most discussion was the second image attached. The pathway to be a recognised professional. This shows not only the education pathway but also the pathway to Member status with the hashtag#CICES and building letters behind your name whilst working.Colleges and Universities need the numbers to be able to run Level 3 Engineering Surveying Course across the country at hashtag#crontoncollege hashtag#dudleycollege hashtag#newsuffolkcollege and hashtag#T3We in hashtag#balfourbeatty have committed to 12 Level 3 Engineering Surveying Apprenticeships to join these colleges in September 2025. Also you dont have to just be on an Engineering Surveying career path - our hashtag#ProjectInformationManagement hashtag#BuildingInformationManagement hashtag#BIM hashtag#GIS apprentices can also join the Level 3 Geospatial Survey Technicain Apprenticeship as well to have a formal education whilst working. So the question is how many are all other hashtag#contractors hashtag#EngineeringSurveying hashtag#Practices hashtag#DesignConsultants hashtag#SupplyPartners going to add to our number to make sure these courses run in 2025 and future years????? hashtag#MakeSpaceforEducation hashtag#BelikeBalfourBeatty hashtag#buildyour hashtag#EngineeringSurveying numbers in 2025 and beyond Thank you to my fellow Balfour Beatty colleagues for getting apprentices approved on their projects Dave Davis Nigel Evans FCInstCES MIMMM Alexander Thurgood Alex Grounds Graeme Ross MCinstCES James Rolland Andy Murphy. ASP.NET Core: Map vs. UseWhen 🤔🟢 What’s the Difference? 🟢 When to Use Which? If you’ve ever worked with middleware in ASP.NET Core, you’ve probably come across Map and UseWhen. At first glance, they seem similar—but they serve different purposes! Let’s break it down in a way that actually makes sense.🎯 Think of Map like a fork in the road.When a request matches a specific path, it permanently takes a separate route (middleware branch).Example: If the request starts with /admin, handle it differently from /user.·Once a request enters a Map branch, it does not return to the main pipeline.🎯 Now, UseWhen is like a side road that merges back.It conditionally applies middleware based on any condition (query params, headers, request type, etc.).But unlike Map, the request returns to the main pipeline afterward.🚀 Example: Imagine a Coffee Shop ☕️Think of an ASP.NET Core middleware pipeline like a coffee shop where customers (requests) come in, get their orders processed, and leave with a response.📌 Map → Separate Lanes for VIPs and Regular Customers In our coffee shop, we have two separate counters:One exclusively for VIP customers.Another for regular customers. If a customer goes to the VIP counter, they never interact with the regular counter.💡 How This Works:If a customer (request) enters /vip, they are directed only to the VIP Rest.If they go anywhere else (/, /home, etc.), they never see the VIP Lounge—they get the regular coffee experience.📌 UseWhen → Special Offers for Customers Wearing Glasses 🤓 Now, let's say the coffee shop offers a discount for customers wearing glasses, but they still follow the same ordering process as everyone else.If someone is wearing glasses, they get extra middleware (discount applied) but still follow the regular checkout.If they aren't wearing glasses, they simply proceed without the discount.💡 How This Works:If the request contains ?glasses=true, it applies the discount (executes the UseWhen middleware).But after the discount is applied, the request continues in the regular pipeline (everyone still gets coffee).If ?glasses=true is not present, the customer still gets coffee but without the discount.🎯 Use Map when requests should take completely separate paths (VIP vs. Regular customers).🎯 Use UseWhen when requests need temporary processing but should still follow the main flow (Glasses discount).

【2024年度QBICプログラム「キャリアと実践Ⅰ 」に学生メンターとして参加】2025年2月8日、QBICプログラムが提供する「キャリアと実践Ⅰ」の最終発表会が行われました。QBICプログラム(Question-Based Innovation and Career education program for societal transition)は、転換期の社会に求められる力を培うための産学速型教育プログラムです。「キャリアと実践Ⅰ」は、本プログラムの科目の一つであり、大阪公立大学の学生が、異なる分野や学年で構成されるグループを作り、「都市大阪の20年後（2045年）の未来社会を創造し，「今」自分たちが取りくむべき課題を設定する」というテーマに取り組みます。グループには、受講生の他に、以前本プログラムを受講していた学生が学生メンターとして、さらに、パナソニックや清水建設、日立製作所、リンクアンドモチベーションなどといった、日本を代表する企業の人事の方が社会人メンターとして加わります。今回も受講生らは、自分とは異なる立場の人達と、20年後の都市大阪の未来を共創する取り組みの中で、「問いを立てる力」と、「学び続ける力」を身につけ、大きく成長させることができました。今回私は、学生メンターとして本プログラムに参加しました。受講生の先輩としてミーティング中にアドバイスしたり、社会人メンターとやりとりしたりし、非常に貴重な経験をさせていただきました。受講生の頃からこれでもかというくらい多くの知識やスキルを与えてくださった市田先生には感謝しかないです。また、本プログラムを主催している先生方や企業の方たちはお金のためにやっているのではなく、日本をよくしていこうという熱いマインドを持たれていて、非常に尊敬しました。本プログラムのさらなる拡大をお祈りしております。この春からいよいよ社会人ですが、熱い心と謙虚な姿勢で社会に価値を与えられる存在になりたいと思います！https://lnkd.in/dbk5rFhZhashtag#大阪公立大学 hashtag#QBIC hashtag#共創

🚨 Dear Fake Recruiters, We See You! 🚨Hey there, legendary "recruiters" of LinkedIn! You know who you are – the ones offering dream jobs with “amazing opportunities” but somehow… things never quite add up. Let’s break down your hiring process, shall we? 😂📢 Step 1: The Perfect Job Post“We’re looking for a highly motivated, dynamic, results-driven individual who can work under pressure, multitask, lead a team, work independently, and also be a team player. Oh, and fresh graduates welcome!”Translation: We have no idea what we want, but we’ll still act like we do.📢 Step 2: The Too-Good-To-Be-True Salary"Salary: Competitive."Translation: You’ll find out at the last stage… or never.📢 Step 3: The Interview ProcessRound 1: A quick call filled with enthusiasm. "You’re the PERFECT fit for this role!"Round 2: A panel interview where no one from the company seems to know who you are.Round 3: A surprise "assignment" requiring 20 hours of unpaid labor.Final Round: Complete silence. Poof! You’ve been ghosted. 👻📢 Step 4: The Random DM Recruiter"Hello dear, I saw your profile and I have a great opportunity for you. Kindly share your CV and WhatsApp number."Bonus Points: If the company name doesn’t exist on Google. 😆To all the real recruiters out there doing an honest job, we salute you! 🫡 But to the fake ones – we see you, and we’re taking screenshots. 😏Tag a friend who's been ghosted or scammed by a fake recruiter! 😂👇hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#Recruitment hashtag#Hiring hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#InterviewTips hashtag#JobHunt hashtag#ResumeTips hashtag#CareerAdvice hashtag#JobSeeker hashtag#WorkLife hashtag#LinkedInHumor hashtag#HiringNow hashtag#JobOpening hashtag#WorkFromHome hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#HRLife hashtag#HumanResources hashtag#Recruiting hashtag#RecruiterLife hashtag#LinkedInNetworking hashtag#FakeJobs hashtag#CareerTips hashtag#InterviewFail hashtag#JobHuntingStruggles hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#ProfessionalGrowth hashtag#LinkedInCommunity hashtag#HiringAlert hashtag#JobInterview hashtag#GhostedByRecruiters hashtag#JobMarket hashtag#ResumeHelp hashtag#CareerMotivation hashtag#WorkplaceHumor hashtag#JobSearchStruggles hashtag#RecruiterFails hashtag#JobScams hashtag#ScamAlert hashtag#JobSeekerJourney hashtag#WorkHardPlayHard hashtag#OfficeHumor hashtag#LinkedInMarketing hashtag#JobOffers hashtag#CorporateHumor hashtag#CareerOppo hashtag#letsconnect

It’s time companies started seeing autistic people as assets, not obstacles!This is the first time I’m openly admitting that I’m autistic (Asperger) beyond my close family and friends. It’s something I’ve kept to myself for a long time because, frankly, it’s not easy. Every word you say can make you feel like an outsider, as if people see you as “weird.” So, the instinct is to hide it, to avoid declaring it, and to struggle against the pressure to conform.But my brother—who works in education and supports people with autism, dyslexia, and other neurodivergences—recently said something that really stuck with me: Autism isn’t a hindrance; it’s a superpower! I was genuinely touched because, honestly, I often worry that he doesn’t see me that way.For example, when I approach a problem, I see the big picture, while many “neurotypical” people focus only on what’s right in front of them. This ability is especially valuable in programming, where structure, logic, and attention to detail are essential. Autistic people often excel in programming and technical fields because of their ability to spot patterns, think systematically, and work with incredible focus.But what’s frustrating is when others can’t see the big picture and block progress because they’re stuck on minor details or rigid ways of thinking. It’s exhausting to have a clear vision of how things should work, only to be told, “That’s not how we do it,” by people who refuse to see beyond their own limited perspective. This is one of the biggest challenges autistic people face in the workplace—not our abilities, but the barriers put in our way by those who don’t understand them.Some companies fail to see the value in this. But the best ones do, and they recognise the incredible strengths that autistic minds bring.This conversation has really lifted my spirits. I love seeing more people acknowledge that autistic individuals have so much to offer when given the right environment to thrive—especially in fields like programming, where our strengths shine!Well done Murphy for setting a new standard!

The call to arms!!! hashtag#EngineeringSurveyingEspisode 3 How many hashtag#EngineeringSurveying hashtag#Apprentices are you employing this year and future years to deliver your hashtag#CivilEngineering hashtag#Projects ????The journey continues increasing numbers of hashtag#EngineeringSurveyors in the industry. Today was the L3 and L6 Geospatial Apprenticeship Trailblazer Group Meeting hosted by Lucy Powers BA (Hons), MBA, FInstCES and Alison Watson MBE. I was invited to present what we Balfour Beatty plc are doing to attract future hashtag#Apprentices in to hashtag#BalfourBeatty. The slide which got the most discussion was the second image attached. The pathway to be a recognised professional. This shows not only the education pathway but also the pathway to Member status with the hashtag#CICES and building letters behind your name whilst working.Colleges and Universities need the numbers to be able to run Level 3 Engineering Surveying Course across the country at hashtag#crontoncollege hashtag#dudleycollege hashtag#newsuffolkcollege and hashtag#T3We in hashtag#balfourbeatty have committed to 12 Level 3 Engineering Surveying Apprenticeships to join these colleges in September 2025. Also you dont have to just be on an Engineering Surveying career path - our hashtag#ProjectInformationManagement hashtag#BuildingInformationManagement hashtag#BIM hashtag#GIS apprentices can also join the Level 3 Geospatial Survey Technicain Apprenticeship as well to have a formal education whilst working. So the question is how many are all other hashtag#contractors hashtag#EngineeringSurveying hashtag#Practices hashtag#DesignConsultants hashtag#SupplyPartners going to add to our number to make sure these courses run in 2025 and future years????? hashtag#MakeSpaceforEducation hashtag#BelikeBalfourBeatty hashtag#buildyour hashtag#EngineeringSurveying numbers in 2025 and beyond Thank you to my fellow Balfour Beatty colleagues for getting apprentices approved on their projects Dave Davis Nigel Evans FCInstCES MIMMM Alexander Thurgood Alex Grounds Graeme Ross MCinstCES James Rolland Andy Murphy. Helpdesk Associate – ITIL

ASP.NET Core: Map vs. UseWhen 🤔🟢 What’s the Difference? 🟢 When to Use Which? If you’ve ever worked with middleware in ASP.NET Core, you’ve probably come across Map and UseWhen. At first glance, they seem similar—but they serve different purposes! Let’s break it down in a way that actually makes sense.🎯 Think of Map like a fork in the road.When a request matches a specific path, it permanently takes a separate route (middleware branch).Example: If the request starts with /admin, handle it differently from /user.·Once a request enters a Map branch, it does not return to the main pipeline.🎯 Now, UseWhen is like a side road that merges back.It conditionally applies middleware based on any condition (query params, headers, request type, etc.).But unlike Map, the request returns to the main pipeline afterward.🚀 Example: Imagine a Coffee Shop ☕️Think of an ASP.NET Core middleware pipeline like a coffee shop where customers (requests) come in, get their orders processed, and leave with a response.📌 Map → Separate Lanes for VIPs and Regular Customers In our coffee shop, we have two separate counters:One exclusively for VIP customers.Another for regular customers. If a customer goes to the VIP counter, they never interact with the regular counter.💡 How This Works:If a customer (request) enters /vip, they are directed only to the VIP Rest.If they go anywhere else (/, /home, etc.), they never see the VIP Lounge—they get the regular coffee experience.📌 UseWhen → Special Offers for Customers Wearing Glasses 🤓 Now, let's say the coffee shop offers a discount for customers wearing glasses, but they still follow the same ordering process as everyone else.If someone is wearing glasses, they get extra middleware (discount applied) but still follow the regular checkout.If they aren't wearing glasses, they simply proceed without the discount.💡 How This Works:If the request contains ?glasses=true, it applies the discount (executes the UseWhen middleware).But after the discount is applied, the request continues in the regular pipeline (everyone still gets coffee).If ?glasses=true is not present, the customer still gets coffee but without the discount.🎯 Use Map when requests should take completely separate paths (VIP vs. Regular customers).🎯 Use UseWhen when requests need temporary processing but should still follow the main flow (Glasses discount).

【2024年度QBICプログラム「キャリアと実践Ⅰ 」に学生メンターとして参加】2025年2月8日、QBICプログラムが提供する「キャリアと実践Ⅰ」の最終発表会が行われました。QBICプログラム(Question-Based Innovation and Career education program for societal transition)は、転換期の社会に求められる力を培うための産学速型教育プログラムです。「キャリアと実践Ⅰ」は、本プログラムの科目の一つであり、大阪公立大学の学生が、異なる分野や学年で構成されるグループを作り、「都市大阪の20年後（2045年）の未来社会を創造し，「今」自分たちが取りくむべき課題を設定する」というテーマに取り組みます。グループには、受講生の他に、以前本プログラムを受講していた学生が学生メンターとして、さらに、パナソニックや清水建設、日立製作所、リンクアンドモチベーションなどといった、日本を代表する企業の人事の方が社会人メンターとして加わります。今回も受講生らは、自分とは異なる立場の人達と、20年後の都市大阪の未来を共創する取り組みの中で、「問いを立てる力」と、「学び続ける力」を身につけ、大きく成長させることができました。今回私は、学生メンターとして本プログラムに参加しました。受講生の先輩としてミーティング中にアドバイスしたり、社会人メンターとやりとりしたりし、非常に貴重な経験をさせていただきました。受講生の頃からこれでもかというくらい多くの知識やスキルを与えてくださった市田先生には感謝しかないです。また、本プログラムを主催している先生方や企業の方たちはお金のためにやっているのではなく、日本をよくしていこうという熱いマインドを持たれていて、非常に尊敬しました。本プログラムのさらなる拡大をお祈りしております。この春からいよいよ社会人ですが、熱い心と謙虚な姿勢で社会に価値を与えられる存在になりたいと思います！https://lnkd.in/dbk5rFhZhashtag#大阪公立大学 hashtag#QBIC hashtag#共創

🚨 Dear Fake Recruiters, We See You! 🚨Hey there, legendary "recruiters" of LinkedIn! You know who you are – the ones offering dream jobs with “amazing opportunities” but somehow… things never quite add up. Let’s break down your hiring process, shall we? 😂📢 Step 1: The Perfect Job Post“We’re looking for a highly motivated, dynamic, results-driven individual who can work under pressure, multitask, lead a team, work independently, and also be a team player. Poof! You’ve been ghosted. 👻📢 Step 4: The Random DM Recruiter"Hello dear, I saw your profile and I have a great opportunity for you. It’s time companies started seeing autistic people as assets, not obstacles!This is the first time I’m openly admitting that I’m autistic (Asperger) beyond my close family and friends. It’s something I’ve kept to myself for a long time because, frankly, it’s not easy. Every word you say can make you feel like an outsider, as if people see you as “weird.” So, the instinct is to hide it, to avoid declaring it, and to struggle against the pressure to conform.But my brother—who works in education and supports people with autism, dyslexia, and other neurodivergences—recently said something that really stuck with me: Autism isn’t a hindrance; it’s a superpower! I was genuinely touched because, honestly, I often worry that he doesn’t see me that way.For example, when I approach a problem, I see the big picture, while many “neurotypical” people focus only on what’s right in front of them. This ability is especially valuable in programming, where structure, logic, and attention to detail are essential. Autistic people often excel in programming and technical fields because of their ability to spot patterns, think systematically, and work with incredible focus.But what’s frustrating is when others can’t see the big picture and block progress because they’re stuck on minor details or rigid ways of thinking. It’s exhausting to have a clear vision of how things should work, only to be told, “That’s not how we do it,” by people who refuse to see beyond their own limited perspective. This is one of the biggest challenges autistic people face in the workplace—not our abilities, but the barriers put in our way by those who don’t understand them.Some companies fail to see the value in this. But the best ones do, and they recognise the incredible strengths that autistic minds bring.This conversation has really lifted my spirits. I love seeing more people acknowledge that autistic individuals have so much to offer when given the right environment to thrive—especially in fields like programming, where our strengths shine!Well done Murphy for setting a new standard!

The call to arms!!! hashtag#EngineeringSurveyingEspisode 3 How many hashtag#EngineeringSurveying hashtag#Apprentices are you employing this year and future years to deliver your hashtag#CivilEngineering hashtag#Projects ????The journey continues increasing numbers of hashtag#EngineeringSurveyors in the industry. ASP.NET Core: Map vs. UseWhen 🤔🟢 What’s the Difference? 🟢 When to Use Which? If you’ve ever worked with middleware in ASP.NET Core, you’ve probably come across Map and UseWhen. At first glance, they seem similar—but they serve different purposes! Let’s break it down in a way that actually makes sense.🎯 Think of Map like a fork in the road.When a request matches a specific path, it permanently takes a separate route (middleware branch).Example: If the request starts with /admin, handle it differently from /user.·Once a request enters a Map branch, it does not return to the main pipeline.🎯 Now, UseWhen is like a side road that merges back.It conditionally applies middleware based on any condition (query params, headers, request type, etc.).But unlike Map, the request returns to the main pipeline afterward.🚀 Example: Imagine a Coffee Shop ☕️Think of an ASP.NET Core middleware pipeline like a coffee shop where customers (requests) come in, get their orders processed, and leave with a response.📌 Map → Separate Lanes for VIPs and Regular Customers In our coffee shop, we have two separate counters:One exclusively for VIP customers.Another for regular customers. If a customer goes to the VIP counter, they never interact with the regular counter.💡 How This Works:If a customer (request) enters /vip, they are directed only to the VIP Rest.If they go anywhere else (/, /home, etc.), they never see the VIP Lounge—they get the regular coffee experience.📌 UseWhen → Special Offers for Customers Wearing Glasses 🤓 Now, let's say the coffee shop offers a discount for customers wearing glasses, but they still follow the same ordering process as everyone else.If someone is wearing glasses, they get extra middleware (discount applied) but still follow the regular checkout.If they aren't wearing glasses, they simply proceed without the discount.💡 How This Works:If the request contains ?glasses=true, it applies the discount (executes the UseWhen middleware).But after the discount is applied, the request continues in the regular pipeline (everyone still gets coffee).If ?glasses=true is not present, the customer still gets coffee but without the discount.🎯 Use Map when requests should take completely separate paths (VIP vs. Regular customers).🎯 Use UseWhen when requests need temporary processing but should still follow the main flow (Glasses discount).

【2024年度QBICプログラム「キャリアと実践Ⅰ 」に学生メンターとして参加】2025年2月8日、QBICプログラムが提供する「キャリアと実践Ⅰ」の最終発表会が行われました。QBICプログラム(Question-Based Innovation and Career education program for societal transition)は、転換期の社会に求められる力を培うための産学速型教育プログラムです。「キャリアと実践Ⅰ」は、本プログラムの科目の一つであり、大阪公立大学の学生が、異なる分野や学年で構成されるグループを作り、「都市大阪の20年後（2045年）の未来社会を創造し，「今」自分たちが取りくむべき課題を設定する」というテーマに取り組みます。グループには、受講生の他に、以前本プログラムを受講していた学生が学生メンターとして、さらに、パナソニックや清水建設、日立製作所、リンクアンドモチベーションなどといった、日本を代表する企業の人事の方が社会人メンターとして加わります。今回も受講生らは、自分とは異なる立場の人達と、20年後の都市大阪の未来を共創する取り組みの中で、「問いを立てる力」と、「学び続ける力」を身につけ、大きく成長させることができました。今回私は、学生メンターとして本プログラムに参加しました。受講生の先輩としてミーティング中にアドバイスしたり、社会人メンターとやりとりしたりし、非常に貴重な経験をさせていただきました。受講生の頃からこれでもかというくらい多くの知識やスキルを与えてくださった市田先生には感謝しかないです。また、本プログラムを主催している先生方や企業の方たちはお金のためにやっているのではなく、日本をよくしていこうという熱いマインドを持たれていて、非常に尊敬しました。本プログラムのさらなる拡大をお祈りしております。この春からいよいよ社会人ですが、熱い心と謙虚な姿勢で社会に価値を与えられる存在になりたいと思います！https://lnkd.in/dbk5rFhZhashtag#大阪公立大学 hashtag#QBIC hashtag#共創

You know who you are – the ones offering dream jobs with “amazing opportunities” but somehow… things never quite add up. Let’s break down your hiring process, shall we? 😂📢 Step 1: The Perfect Job Post“We’re looking for a highly motivated, dynamic, results-driven individual who can work under pressure, multitask, lead a team, work independently, and also be a team player. Poof! You’ve been ghosted. 👻📢 Step 4: The Random DM Recruiter"Hello dear, I saw your profile and I have a great opportunity for you. It’s time companies started seeing autistic people as assets, not obstacles!This is the first time I’m openly admitting that I’m autistic (Asperger) beyond my close family and friends. It’s something I’ve kept to myself for a long time because, frankly, it’s not easy. Every word you say can make you feel like an outsider, as if people see you as “weird.” So, the instinct is to hide it, to avoid declaring it, and to struggle against the pressure to conform.But my brother—who works in education and supports people with autism, dyslexia, and other neurodivergences—recently said something that really stuck with me: Autism isn’t a hindrance; it’s a superpower! I was genuinely touched because, honestly, I often worry that he doesn’t see me that way.For example, when I approach a problem, I see the big picture, while many “neurotypical” people focus only on what’s right in front of them. This ability is especially valuable in programming, where structure, logic, and attention to detail are essential. Autistic people often excel in programming and technical fields because of their ability to spot patterns, think systematically, and work with incredible focus.But what’s frustrating is when others can’t see the big picture and block progress because they’re stuck on minor details or rigid ways of thinking. It’s exhausting to have a clear vision of how things should work, only to be told, “That’s not how we do it,” by people who refuse to see beyond their own limited perspective. This is one of the biggest challenges autistic people face in the workplace—not our abilities, but the barriers put in our way by those who don’t understand them.Some companies fail to see the value in this. But the best ones do, and they recognise the incredible strengths that autistic minds bring.This conversation has really lifted my spirits. I love seeing more people acknowledge that autistic individuals have so much to offer when given the right environment to thrive—especially in fields like programming, where our strengths shine!Well done Murphy for setting a new standard!

What do job seekers need to know about the current labor market?LinkedIn Chief Economist Karin Kimbrough joins LinkedIn News Editor Andrew Seaman on a bonus episode of the hashtag#GetHired newsletter to break down the latest economic and workforce data for job seekers. The two discuss the seemingly conflicting realities of a "healthy" labor market while job seekers struggle to get interviews. Karin also says:📊 The job market is solid but hiring is sluggish, leading to increased competition for available roles.💻 The demand for AI-related jobs is rising, so job seekers should upskill in AI tools.🧑‍🏫 Employers value a combination of human and technical skills, so job seekers should develop both. Check out all of Karin's insights on the latest episode of hashtag#GetHired at the link below where you'll find an audio player and transcript. You can also listen to the conversation on your favorite podcast player by clicking here: https://lnkd.in/dR556KCJYou can also find addition insights from Karin's team in the newsletter State of the Labor Market: https://lnkd.in/dQEhqnw5

Helpdesk Associate – ITIL

ASP.NET Core: Map vs. UseWhen 🤔🟢 What’s the Difference? 🟢 When to Use Which? If you’ve ever worked with middleware in ASP.NET Core, you’ve probably come across Map and UseWhen. At first glance, they seem similar—but they serve different purposes! Let’s break it down in a way that actually makes sense.🎯 Think of Map like a fork in the road.When a request matches a specific path, it permanently takes a separate route (middleware branch).Example: If the request starts with /admin, handle it differently from /user.·Once a request enters a Map branch, it does not return to the main pipeline.🎯 Now, UseWhen is like a side road that merges back.It conditionally applies middleware based on any condition (query params, headers, request type, etc.).But unlike Map, the request returns to the main pipeline afterward.🚀 Example: Imagine a Coffee Shop ☕️Think of an ASP.NET Core middleware pipeline like a coffee shop where customers (requests) come in, get their orders processed, and leave with a response.📌 Map → Separate Lanes for VIPs and Regular Customers In our coffee shop, we have two separate counters:One exclusively for VIP customers.Another for regular customers. If a customer goes to the VIP counter, they never interact with the regular counter.💡 How This Works:If a customer (request) enters /vip, they are directed only to the VIP Rest.If they go anywhere else (/, /home, etc.), they never see the VIP Lounge—they get the regular coffee experience.📌 UseWhen → Special Offers for Customers Wearing Glasses 🤓 Now, let's say the coffee shop offers a discount for customers wearing glasses, but they still follow the same ordering process as everyone else.If someone is wearing glasses, they get extra middleware (discount applied) but still follow the regular checkout.If they aren't wearing glasses, they simply proceed without the discount.💡 How This Works:If the request contains ?glasses=true, it applies the discount (executes the UseWhen middleware).But after the discount is applied, the request continues in the regular pipeline (everyone still gets coffee).If ?glasses=true is not present, the customer still gets coffee but without the discount.🎯 Use Map when requests should take completely separate paths (VIP vs. Regular customers).🎯 Use UseWhen when requests need temporary processing but should still follow the main flow (Glasses discount).

【2024年度QBICプログラム「キャリアと実践Ⅰ 」に学生メンターとして参加】2025年2月8日、QBICプログラムが提供する「キャリアと実践Ⅰ」の最終発表会が行われました。QBICプログラム(Question-Based Innovation and Career education program for societal transition)は、転換期の社会に求められる力を培うための産学速型教育プログラムです。「キャリアと実践Ⅰ」は、本プログラムの科目の一つであり、大阪公立大学の学生が、異なる分野や学年で構成されるグループを作り、「都市大阪の20年後（2045年）の未来社会を創造し，「今」自分たちが取りくむべき課題を設定する」というテーマに取り組みます。グループには、受講生の他に、以前本プログラムを受講していた学生が学生メンターとして、さらに、パナソニックや清水建設、日立製作所、リンクアンドモチベーションなどといった、日本を代表する企業の人事の方が社会人メンターとして加わります。今回も受講生らは、自分とは異なる立場の人達と、20年後の都市大阪の未来を共創する取り組みの中で、「問いを立てる力」と、「学び続ける力」を身につけ、大きく成長させることができました。今回私は、学生メンターとして本プログラムに参加しました。受講生の先輩としてミーティング中にアドバイスしたり、社会人メンターとやりとりしたりし、非常に貴重な経験をさせていただきました。受講生の頃からこれでもかというくらい多くの知識やスキルを与えてくださった市田先生には感謝しかないです。また、本プログラムを主催している先生方や企業の方たちはお金のためにやっているのではなく、日本をよくしていこうという熱いマインドを持たれていて、非常に尊敬しました。本プログラムのさらなる拡大をお祈りしております。この春からいよいよ社会人ですが、熱い心と謙虚な姿勢で社会に価値を与えられる存在になりたいと思います！https://lnkd.in/dbk5rFhZhashtag#大阪公立大学 hashtag#QBIC hashtag#共創

It’s time companies started seeing autistic people as assets, not obstacles!This is the first time I’m openly admitting that I’m autistic (Asperger) beyond my close family and friends. It’s something I’ve kept to myself for a long time because, frankly, it’s not easy. Every word you say can make you feel like an outsider, as if people see you as “weird.” So, the instinct is to hide it, to avoid declaring it, and to struggle against the pressure to conform.But my brother—who works in education and supports people with autism, dyslexia, and other neurodivergences—recently said something that really stuck with me: Autism isn’t a hindrance; it’s a superpower! I was genuinely touched because, honestly, I often worry that he doesn’t see me that way.For example, when I approach a problem, I see the big picture, while many “neurotypical” people focus only on what’s right in front of them. This ability is especially valuable in programming, where structure, logic, and attention to detail are essential. Autistic people often excel in programming and technical fields because of their ability to spot patterns, think systematically, and work with incredible focus.But what’s frustrating is when others can’t see the big picture and block progress because they’re stuck on minor details or rigid ways of thinking. It’s exhausting to have a clear vision of how things should work, only to be told, “That’s not how we do it,” by people who refuse to see beyond their own limited perspective. This is one of the biggest challenges autistic people face in the workplace—not our abilities, but the barriers put in our way by those who don’t understand them.Some companies fail to see the value in this. But the best ones do, and they recognise the incredible strengths that autistic minds bring.This conversation has really lifted my spirits. I love seeing more people acknowledge that autistic individuals have so much to offer when given the right environment to thrive—especially in fields like programming, where our strengths shine!Well done Murphy for setting a new standard!

Post Content:
What do job seekers need to know about the current labor market?LinkedIn Chief Economist Karin Kimbrough joins LinkedIn News Editor Andrew Seaman on a bonus episode of the hashtag#GetHired newsletter to break down the latest economic and workforce data for job seekers. The two discuss the seemingly conflicting realities of a "healthy" labor market while job seekers struggle to get interviews. Karin also says:📊 The job market is solid but hiring is sluggish, leading to increased competition for available roles.💻 The demand for AI-related jobs is rising, so job seekers should upskill in AI tools.🧑‍🏫 Employers value a combination of human and technical skills, so job seekers should develop both. Check out all of Karin's insights on the latest episode of hashtag#GetHired at the link below where you'll find an audio player and transcript. You can also listen to the conversation on your favorite podcast player by clicking here: https://lnkd.in/dR556KCJYou can also find addition insights from Karin's team in the newsletter State of the Labor Market: https://lnkd.in/dQEhqnw5

ASP.NET Core: Map vs. UseWhen 🤔🟢 What’s the Difference? 🟢 When to Use Which? If you’ve ever worked with middleware in ASP.NET Core, you’ve probably come across Map and UseWhen. At first glance, they seem similar—but they serve different purposes! Let’s break it down in a way that actually makes sense.🎯 Think of Map like a fork in the road.When a request matches a specific path, it permanently takes a separate route (middleware branch).Example: If the request starts with /admin, handle it differently from /user.·Once a request enters a Map branch, it does not return to the main pipeline.🎯 Now, UseWhen is like a side road that merges back.It conditionally applies middleware based on any condition (query params, headers, request type, etc.).But unlike Map, the request returns to the main pipeline afterward.🚀 Example: Imagine a Coffee Shop ☕️Think of an ASP.NET Core middleware pipeline like a coffee shop where customers (requests) come in, get their orders processed, and leave with a response.📌 Map → Separate Lanes for VIPs and Regular Customers In our coffee shop, we have two separate counters:One exclusively for VIP customers.Another for regular customers. If a customer goes to the VIP counter, they never interact with the regular counter.💡 How This Works:If a customer (request) enters /vip, they are directed only to the VIP Rest.If they go anywhere else (/, /home, etc.), they never see the VIP Lounge—they get the regular coffee experience.📌 UseWhen → Special Offers for Customers Wearing Glasses 🤓 Now, let's say the coffee shop offers a discount for customers wearing glasses, but they still follow the same ordering process as everyone else.If someone is wearing glasses, they get extra middleware (discount applied) but still follow the regular checkout.If they aren't wearing glasses, they simply proceed without the discount.💡 How This Works:If the request contains ?glasses=true, it applies the discount (executes the UseWhen middleware).But after the discount is applied, the request continues in the regular pipeline (everyone still gets coffee).If ?glasses=true is not present, the customer still gets coffee but without the discount.🎯 Use Map when requests should take completely separate paths (VIP vs. Regular customers).🎯 Use UseWhen when requests need temporary processing but should still follow the main flow (Glasses discount).

【2024年度QBICプログラム「キャリアと実践Ⅰ 」に学生メンターとして参加】2025年2月8日、QBICプログラムが提供する「キャリアと実践Ⅰ」の最終発表会が行われました。QBICプログラム(Question-Based Innovation and Career education program for societal transition)は、転換期の社会に求められる力を培うための産学速型教育プログラムです。「キャリアと実践Ⅰ」は、本プログラムの科目の一つであり、大阪公立大学の学生が、異なる分野や学年で構成されるグループを作り、「都市大阪の20年後（2045年）の未来社会を創造し，「今」自分たちが取りくむべき課題を設定する」というテーマに取り組みます。グループには、受講生の他に、以前本プログラムを受講していた学生が学生メンターとして、さらに、パナソニックや清水建設、日立製作所、リンクアンドモチベーションなどといった、日本を代表する企業の人事の方が社会人メンターとして加わります。今回も受講生らは、自分とは異なる立場の人達と、20年後の都市大阪の未来を共創する取り組みの中で、「問いを立てる力」と、「学び続ける力」を身につけ、大きく成長させることができました。今回私は、学生メンターとして本プログラムに参加しました。受講生の先輩としてミーティング中にアドバイスしたり、社会人メンターとやりとりしたりし、非常に貴重な経験をさせていただきました。受講生の頃からこれでもかというくらい多くの知識やスキルを与えてくださった市田先生には感謝しかないです。また、本プログラムを主催している先生方や企業の方たちはお金のためにやっているのではなく、日本をよくしていこうという熱いマインドを持たれていて、非常に尊敬しました。本プログラムのさらなる拡大をお祈りしております。この春からいよいよ社会人ですが、熱い心と謙虚な姿勢で社会に価値を与えられる存在になりたいと思います！https://lnkd.in/dbk5rFhZhashtag#大阪公立大学 hashtag#QBIC hashtag#共創

🚨 Dear Fake Recruiters, We See You! 🚨Hey there, legendary "recruiters" of LinkedIn! You know who you are – the ones offering dream jobs with “amazing opportunities” but somehow… things never quite add up. Let’s break down your hiring process, shall we? 😂📢 Step 1: The Perfect Job Post“We’re looking for a highly motivated, dynamic, results-driven individual who can work under pressure, multitask, lead a team, work independently, and also be a team player. Oh, and fresh graduates welcome!”Translation: We have no idea what we want, but we’ll still act like we do.📢 Step 2: The Too-Good-To-Be-True Salary"Salary: Competitive."Translation: You’ll find out at the last stage… or never.📢 Step 3: The Interview ProcessRound 1: A quick call filled with enthusiasm. "You’re the PERFECT fit for this role!"Round 2: A panel interview where no one from the company seems to know who you are.Round 3: A surprise "assignment" requiring 20 hours of unpaid labor.Final Round: Complete silence. Poof! You’ve been ghosted. 👻📢 Step 4: The Random DM Recruiter"Hello dear, I saw your profile and I have a great opportunity for you. Kindly share your CV and WhatsApp number."Bonus Points: If the company name doesn’t exist on Google. 😆To all the real recruiters out there doing an honest job, we salute you! 🫡 But to the fake ones – we see you, and we’re taking screenshots. 😏Tag a friend who's been ghosted or scammed by a fake recruiter! 😂👇hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#Recruitment hashtag#Hiring hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#InterviewTips hashtag#JobHunt hashtag#ResumeTips hashtag#CareerAdvice hashtag#JobSeeker hashtag#WorkLife hashtag#LinkedInHumor hashtag#HiringNow hashtag#JobOpening hashtag#WorkFromHome hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#HRLife hashtag#HumanResources hashtag#Recruiting hashtag#RecruiterLife hashtag#LinkedInNetworking hashtag#FakeJobs hashtag#CareerTips hashtag#InterviewFail hashtag#JobHuntingStruggles hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#ProfessionalGrowth hashtag#LinkedInCommunity hashtag#HiringAlert hashtag#JobInterview hashtag#GhostedByRecruiters hashtag#JobMarket hashtag#ResumeHelp hashtag#CareerMotivation hashtag#WorkplaceHumor hashtag#JobSearchStruggles hashtag#RecruiterFails hashtag#JobScams hashtag#ScamAlert hashtag#JobSeekerJourney hashtag#WorkHardPlayHard hashtag#OfficeHumor hashtag#LinkedInMarketing hashtag#JobOffers hashtag#CorporateHumor hashtag#CareerOppo hashtag#letsconnect

It’s time companies started seeing autistic people as assets, not obstacles!This is the first time I’m openly admitting that I’m autistic (Asperger) beyond my close family and friends. It’s something I’ve kept to myself for a long time because, frankly, it’s not easy. Every word you say can make you feel like an outsider, as if people see you as “weird.” So, the instinct is to hide it, to avoid declaring it, and to struggle against the pressure to conform.But my brother—who works in education and supports people with autism, dyslexia, and other neurodivergences—recently said something that really stuck with me: Autism isn’t a hindrance; it’s a superpower! I was genuinely touched because, honestly, I often worry that he doesn’t see me that way.For example, when I approach a problem, I see the big picture, while many “neurotypical” people focus only on what’s right in front of them. This ability is especially valuable in programming, where structure, logic, and attention to detail are essential. Autistic people often excel in programming and technical fields because of their ability to spot patterns, think systematically, and work with incredible focus.But what’s frustrating is when others can’t see the big picture and block progress because they’re stuck on minor details or rigid ways of thinking. It’s exhausting to have a clear vision of how things should work, only to be told, “That’s not how we do it,” by people who refuse to see beyond their own limited perspective. This is one of the biggest challenges autistic people face in the workplace—not our abilities, but the barriers put in our way by those who don’t understand them.Some companies fail to see the value in this. But the best ones do, and they recognise the incredible strengths that autistic minds bring.This conversation has really lifted my spirits. I love seeing more people acknowledge that autistic individuals have so much to offer when given the right environment to thrive—especially in fields like programming, where our strengths shine!Well done Murphy for setting a new standard!

The call to arms!!! hashtag#EngineeringSurveyingEspisode 3 How many hashtag#EngineeringSurveying hashtag#Apprentices are you employing this year and future years to deliver your hashtag#CivilEngineering hashtag#Projects ????The journey continues increasing numbers of hashtag#EngineeringSurveyors in the industry. Today was the L3 and L6 Geospatial Apprenticeship Trailblazer Group Meeting hosted by Lucy Powers BA (Hons), MBA, FInstCES and Alison Watson MBE. I was invited to present what we Balfour Beatty plc are doing to attract future hashtag#Apprentices in to hashtag#BalfourBeatty. The slide which got the most discussion was the second image attached. The pathway to be a recognised professional. This shows not only the education pathway but also the pathway to Member status with the hashtag#CICES and building letters behind your name whilst working.Colleges and Universities need the numbers to be able to run Level 3 Engineering Surveying Course across the country at hashtag#crontoncollege hashtag#dudleycollege hashtag#newsuffolkcollege and hashtag#T3We in hashtag#balfourbeatty have committed to 12 Level 3 Engineering Surveying Apprenticeships to join these colleges in September 2025. Also you dont have to just be on an Engineering Surveying career path - our hashtag#ProjectInformationManagement hashtag#BuildingInformationManagement hashtag#BIM hashtag#GIS apprentices can also join the Level 3 Geospatial Survey Technicain Apprenticeship as well to have a formal education whilst working. So the question is how many are all other hashtag#contractors hashtag#EngineeringSurveying hashtag#Practices hashtag#DesignConsultants hashtag#SupplyPartners going to add to our number to make sure these courses run in 2025 and future years????? hashtag#MakeSpaceforEducation hashtag#BelikeBalfourBeatty hashtag#buildyour hashtag#EngineeringSurveying numbers in 2025 and beyond Thank you to my fellow Balfour Beatty colleagues for getting apprentices approved on their projects Dave Davis Nigel Evans FCInstCES MIMMM Alexander Thurgood Alex Grounds Graeme Ross MCinstCES James Rolland Andy Murphy. Post Content:
What do job seekers need to know about the current labor market?LinkedIn Chief Economist Karin Kimbrough joins LinkedIn News Editor Andrew Seaman on a bonus episode of the hashtag#GetHired newsletter to break down the latest economic and workforce data for job seekers. The two discuss the seemingly conflicting realities of a "healthy" labor market while job seekers struggle to get interviews. Karin also says:📊 The job market is solid but hiring is sluggish, leading to increased competition for available roles.💻 The demand for AI-related jobs is rising, so job seekers should upskill in AI tools.🧑‍🏫 Employers value a combination of human and technical skills, so job seekers should develop both. Check out all of Karin's insights on the latest episode of hashtag#GetHired at the link below where you'll find an audio player and transcript. You can also listen to the conversation on your favorite podcast player by clicking here: https://lnkd.in/dR556KCJYou can also find addition insights from Karin's team in the newsletter State of the Labor Market: https://lnkd.in/dQEhqnw5

"You should be skilled in Jira"What does Jira mean? I responded I like Jira (cumin)-Lahsun (garlic)-Adrak (ginger)-Dhania(coriander) in liberal quantities in my mutton curry.The hiring company wants a Data Architect of SAP vintage. Esp. expert in Supply Chain Planning. The engagement manager added 10 more lines of JD.PS: I never used any project management tool. It's a nuisance for me. I do my project management on notepad. The only project management tool I know. The other tool I know is email.Advice to recruiters: Stick to the CORE. Why do you need someone like me? What is the context of hiring? Ask for a quote. Time and Material is a total fraud. I can be onboard for just 2 samosas and 3 teas a day if you are sensitized. I will pay for my own airfare. My ancestors left me millions of dollars in largesse.hashtag#projectmanagement

Almost two years ago, I decided to move to Denmark  🇩🇰 - without really knowing where to start.I didn’t speak Danish, I didn’t know anyone, I had no network... and even though I was full of motivation and eager to work in marketing, the reality wasn’t easy.The doors didn’t open. Many positions required fluent Danish – or they chose candidates with more experience than me. There were times when I thought it would never happen, that maybe it just wasn’t possible.But fate brought a very special person into my life: Oluf C. Lund.Oluf didn’t just offer his help – he gave me something far more valuable: trust, wisdom, and constant support every step of the way. He encouraged me to learn Danish, improve my professional profile, and – most importantly – not to give up. He gave me back hope, right when I needed it the most.Thanks to his support and our shared efforts, I can now say that I’ve been working for two and a half months as Junior Content Specialist at BoConcept – a company I truly admire, and where I feel lucky to grow every day surrounded by an amazing team. I learn something new every single day, and it’s both enriching and motivating.This post is for you, Oluf – thank you from the bottom of my heart.And also for those in my network who might be in a situation similar to the one I was in not long ago.Don’t give up. Surround yourself with people who inspire you, keep learning, be patient and – above all – trust your path. Sometimes, the first step is finding someone who believes in you before you believe in yourself.That’s the best advice I can give you.Thank you for everything, Oluf.
